Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I improved my german speaking, reading, and writing skills as well as my comprehension ability.
You will improve your German language skills in terms of speaking, writing, listening and reading. A natural continuation of first semester intensive.
I was able to improve my proficiency in German grammar, learn relevant vocabulary, practise conversation and learn cultural details.
Continued development of German speaking, writing, reading, and listening skills.

I acquired a greater facility with writing and reading, and listening and speaking in German. My ability to comprehend has increased, including my ability to figure out what someone is saying even if I do not know every word that is spoken or written.
German speaking, reading, and writing skills. Cultural knowledge of Germany, Austria, and Switzerland.

The course has very few weaknesses, if any at all. An engaged and talented professor makes the hours fly by, and the fact that everyone in the class was committed to learning as much german as possible ensured that the classroom environment was maximally conducive to language learning. The textbook exercises might have been the only weakness of the course.
The course did a good job of building upon L1/L2 grammar while also introducing German culture. While we got a lot of practice speaking, I would've maybe liked to work on proper pronunciation more.

Frau Sippel is the main strength of this course!!! If she is teaching, I couldn't recommend this course. She is a highly intelligent, patient and kind professor. She does a great job providing supplementary materials outside the textbook which makes class more exciting. She also does a good job providing individual feedback. The textbook exercises at times can get tedious (as can the homework) but beside that I cannot imagine a better course to improve German language skills.
Great course, well taught. Quia is the only downfall - it's a horrible homework tool.

The greatest strength of the course is Professor Sippel and her engagement with her students. The course is also always well organized, and concepts are explained fully and clearly. I also always love when we discuss culture or history, or look at authentic German sources, whether it be a movie or article. Perhaps the only thing that I would change would be focus on the textbook exercises. Many of the exercises are simple or repetitive and while they of course provide practice, we perhaps don't get as much out of them as we do from the more interesting and challenging activities from Professor Sippel.

I would have preferred to work with a different textbook. I enjoyed learning about the different cities in Germany, Austria, and Switzerland, but I think I would have been more excited with another textbook. 
Im really happy with how much learning was interactive. This was one of the best parts of the course.

The course, and especially Frau Sippel, was amazing. The greatest strength was Frau Sippel-- her patience, thoughtfulness, and intentionality in teaching the class. She made the class fun and engaging through the games we played and the creative activities she produced. The greater emphasis on hearing and listening, whether through movies or videos, was an important element in course.

Although the time constraints might not allow, the only improvement I'd suggest is incorporating more review throughout the semester. The book did have some review built into its structure, but I think if we had an hour each week to review sentence structures, vocabulary, it would have enhanced our retention.

Strengths: There was a lot of time in class to practice speaking German (group activities, class discussion, etc.). Daily homework and weekly tests provide constant feedback. Frau Sippel cares a lot about her students.
Absolutely. If you finish GMAN 125 then this class really is a must-take. Especially if Frau Sippel is teaching it!
Yes! If you have any desire to reach a B1 level of German language skills, I could not recommend this course more!
Yes if you want to get to L4 quickly. If you want to develop proficiency it might be worth your while to take the longer cycle.
Definitely. Intensive German is such a great way develop German skills in a shorter time without any sacrifice or missing out on the foundations.
If anyone was interested in learning German I would (and have) highly recommended not only German but the intensive German section.

I would recommend this course to students that are passionate about learning languages and are willing to dedicate a large chunk of time to learning German. Having a class every morning for 100 minutes can limit other academic opportunities, but it is worth it for students that are serious about learning German.
